oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jet Signatures in the Spectra of Accreting Black Holes
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Riordan, Michael O'
Pe'er, Asaf
McKinney, Jonathan C.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Astrophysics - High Energy Astrophysical Phenomena
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Jets are observed as radio emission in active galactic nuclei and during the low/hard state in X-ray binaries (XRBs), but their contribution at higher frequencies has been uncertain. We study the dynamics of jets in XRBs using the general-relativistic magnetohydrodynamic code HARM. We calculate the high-energy spectra and variability properties using a general-relativistic radiative transport code based on grmonty. We find the following signatures of jet emission (i) a significant gamma-ray peak above ~10^22 Hz, (ii) a break in the optical/UV spectrum, with a change in luminosity from L ~ nu^0 to L ~ nu, followed by another break at higher frequencies where the spectrum roughly returns to L ~ nu^0, and (iii) a pronounced synchrotron peak near or below ~10^14 Hz indicates that a significant fraction of any observed X-ray emission originates in the jet. We investigate the variability during a large-scale magnetic field inversion in which the Blandford-Znajek (BZ) jet is quenched and a new transient hot reconnecting plasmoid is launched by the reconnecting field. The ratio of the gamma-rays to X-rays changes from L_gamma / L_X > 1 in the BZ jet to L_gamma / L_X < 1 during the launching of the transient plasmoid.
Comment: 12 pages, 11 figures, added new section on density floors and extended the discussion of MAD model variability, accepted for publication in Ap.J
